div1.p: Carter discusses Henry Carter, Jr., and the contribution his work has made to the war effort.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura Armistead Carter, July 4, 1917
div1.opener:
OFFICE OF
MALARIAL INVESTIGATIONS
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
U. S. MARINE HOSPITAL
NEW ORLEANS. LA.
Petersburg Va
July 4/17
My Dear Little Daughter:
div1.p:
Both of your letters came last night. I too
am very sorry. I the more so that I feel sure that the
decision is erroneous, Now This is really a cause of congratulation. My suggestion would be (1) to
do what H. proposes or (2) to see the Ex'g Board in Balt.
& find out whether the alleged disability is tem-
porary or permanent, & if the former see if he can't
apply again. I sh'd think that there would be no af-
fection to telling him the nature of the disabil-
ity. Our Boards do, & the navy Boards also, at
least sometimes

Possibly his plan is better - I rather think it is,
I can think if only 2 things which could have
disqualified him (1) under weight due to
C1
B22
2
his recent sickness &(2) albuminuria
or the history of Albuminuria. The
1st is clearly temporary- He is usually full
weight, even under very spare diet. For the 2d
Thayer's certificate, given some time ago, ought to
clear the matter up. Thayer is or was a Consultant to a
member of the Army Ex'g Boards, & told me
that his advice was frequently asked or doubt-
ful cases & (as I understood) accepted. It could
get another Certif. from Thayer I presume if he
(T.) is in this country. I heard that he had gone to
Russia. Homman & Fulcher would proba-
bly do as well in that case. He. was free from
Albuminuria a short while ago &, I under-
stood, was told that he was free from it by the examin-
er in Baltimore. I am very sorry for him.
Of
3
Of course if he is disqualified he
should not go.- but I don't think that he is,

I don't know what to say of the Br. or Canadian, plan. The
last sentence above is true, independent of my
opinion of his fitness.

Send me (1) package litte envelopes - prefera-
bly penalty (2) '' smallest sick long envelopes
not addressed:

I go to Quantico this afternoon- I returned
there from Monday night. There is considera-
ble of Mal. work to be done there & It some
typhoid prevention for which I take Waller
& Crohurst. I believe I have done some
good- to “help win the war”- here & that
we can do more at Q. If we can save the
lives of 3 soldiers & marines-it will pay &
with a saving of considerable disability from
sickness as an extra credit. I think we
C1
B20
4
will do more than that & I am glad. My being
able to hold Va. only LeP. or myself could do so-
release LeP. for work about the Western
Camps- worth I Judge- 100 lives at least & much
disability- That is better than going with
Guiteras. I am inclined to think
that Wrightson will be assigned to Quantico
I suggested it strongly but did not ask it,

No quarters at Q. & My Address will be
after today- “Princess Anne Hotel- Fred-
ericksburg Va” - going up every morning & get-
ting back (6.20) every afternoon. What is
the address of Sally Carter's father?

I am getting another rattan suitcase for
my clothes I have more than I wanthave room
for- Judge that I will have to get a Campaign
5
hat, & possibly a new pair of Khaki riding
trousers- If I need them I will get them from
Young. Expect to be in Norfolk- or in
that vicinity- within 7 to 10 days. One thing
that has held me back was that I did not
want to go wading in the swamps with a
Col's insignia. At Q, I have, Theodore Hayne;
Snidow & clive of Va state Board: & will
have Griffitts if I need him & Waller & Crohurst
so I can lel leave that out, except where
necessary to demonstrate something.

I agree with what you say about Washington
& will I think be able to visit it with you later
Oh. my Dear: I hate things to fall on you.
Not that you are not enduring- wisely &
bravely enduring- but you haven't the in-
sensitiveness- which comes with old age
C1
B20
6
w'h is physical I Judge & “used to it.” We,
you especially, have had a “hard row
to hoe.” Never thele And although we are both
constitutionally better filled for doing than
for bearing things yet please God we have
both borne all that was put on us & done
a good part of all that we could in addition.

Glad am I, however, of Brown's report as to your
internal “geography” & I hope the functional
part will follow suit we have helped already in
this way & may do as much as Joe Hayden yet a good
part of my work is
due to your help

I must stop now other letters
Give my dear love to your mother &
to Mary & Henry & Ned. What of Sylvia?

I don't write very often because I am saving my
self. One day, Monday, I was up from 6. to 11.10.30P.M
in & was not hurt by it (at Q.) but I lie down
some of every day.- less than was necessary at Norfolk. I am
not so strong as I was before the grippe- but seem to be steadily
gaining
